Chattanooga is home to the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga (UTC) and Chattanooga State Community College.

column1: The first inhabitants of the Chattanooga area were Native Americans. Sites dating back to the Upper Paleolithic period (ca. 10
column2: 000 bce) show continuous human occupation through the Archaic
column3: Woodland
column4: Mississippian/Muskogean/Yuchi (900–1714 ce)
column5: and Cherokee (1776–1838) periods. The Chickamauga Mound near the mouth of the Chickamauga Creek is the oldest (ca. 750 ce) remaining visible art in Chattanooga.

column1: The Citico town and mound site was the most significant Mississippian/Muscogee landmark in Chattanooga up to 1915. The first part of the name "Chattanooga" derives from the Muskogean word cvto /chắtȯ/ – 'rock'. The latter may be derived from a regional suffix -nuga meaning dwelling or dwelling place. It is also believed to be derived from the Creek Indian word for ‘rock rising to a point.’
The earliest Cherokee occupation of the area dates from 1776
column2: when Dragging Canoe separated himself from the main tribe to establish resistance to European settlement during the Cherokee–American wars. In 1816 John Ross
column3: who later became Principal Chief
column4: established Ross's Landing. Located along what is now Broad Street
column5: it became one of the centers of Cherokee Nation settlement
column6: which also extended into Georgia and Alabama.In 1838
column7: the U.S. government forced the Cherokees
column8: along with other Native Americans
column9: to relocate to the area designated as Indian Territory
column10: in what is now the state of Oklahoma. Their journey west became known as the "Trail of Tears" for their exile and fatalities along the way. The U.S. Army used Ross's Landing as the site of one of three large internment camps
column12: where Native Americans were held before the journey on the Trail of Tears.

column2: the community of Ross's Landing incorporated as the city of Chattanooga. The city grew quickly
column3: initially benefiting from a location well-suited for river commerce. With the arrival of the railroad in 1850
column4: Chattanooga became a boom town. The city was known as the site "where cotton meets corn
column5:
referring to its location along the cultural boundary between the mountain communities of southern Appalachia and the cotton-growing states to the south. 


=== Civil War ===
During the American Civil War, Chattanooga was a center of battle. Chattanooga served as a hub connecting fifty percent the Confederacy's arsenals, those being located in Atlanta, Augusta, Columbus, and Macon. Chattanooga railroads proved vital in the Confederacy's transportation of raw material to processing plants where they were responsible for producing small arms munitions. During the Chickamauga Campaign, Union artillery bombarded Chattanooga as a diversion and occupied it on September 9, 1863. Following the Battle of Chickamauga, the defeated Union Army retreated to safety in Chattanooga. On November 23, 1863, the Battles for Chattanooga began when Union forces led by Major General Ulysses S. Grant reinforced troops at Chattanooga and advanced to Orchard Knob against Confederate troops besieging the city. The next day, the Battle of Lookout Mountain was fought, driving the Confederates off the mountain. On November 25, Grant's army routed the Confederates in the Battle of Missionary Ridge. In regard to victories won by the Union, Chattanooga marks one of three defining moments that turned the Civil War in their favor. The Battle of Gettysburg brought the streak of victories obtained by the Confederacy to an end, while the Siege of Vicksburg split the Confederacy itself in half, while Chattanooga served doorway to the deep south. These battles were followed the next spring by the Atlanta Campaign, beginning just over the nearby state line in Georgia and moving southeastward. After the war ended, the city became a major railroad hub and industrial and manufacturing center.


=== 1867 flood ===
The largest flood in Chattanooga's history occurred in 1867, before the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) system was created in 1933 by Congress. The flood crested at 58 feet (18 m) and completely inundated the city. Since the completion of the reservoir system, the highest Chattanooga flood stage has been nearly 37 feet (11 m), which occurred in 1973. Without regulation, the flood would have crested at 52.4 feet (16.0 m). Chattanooga was a major priority in the design of the TVA reservoir system and remains a major operating priority in the 21st century.


=== 20th Century ===

In December 1906, Chattanooga was in the national headlines in United States v. Shipp, as the United States Supreme Court, in the only criminal trial in its history, ruled that Hamilton County Sheriff Joseph H. Shipp had violated Ed Johnson's civil rights when Shipp allowed a mob to enter the Hamilton County jail and lynch Johnson on the Walnut Street Bridge.
Chattanooga grew with the entry of the United States in the First World War in 1917; the nearest training camp was in Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia. The Influenza of 1918 closed local movie theaters and pool halls. By the 1930s, Chattanooga was known as the Dynamo of Dixie"

The Championships' debut in Chattanooga marked the first time in the event's 29-year history that women were allowed to compete for professional national titles. column1: The city operates under a charter granted by the state legislature in 1852; the charter has been subsequently amended.
The city operates under a strong mayor system
column2: which changed from a commission form of government with members voted at-large. In 1987 twelve African American city residents filed a complaint
column3: Brown v. Board of Commissioners of the City of Chattanooga
column4: alleging that the commission-style government violated their civil rights
column5: including the Voting Rights Act of 1965
column6: by diluting the minority black vote. In 1989 U.S. District Judge R. Allan Edgar ruled in their favor
column7: compelling the city to abandon the at-large voting system that it had used for the 'commission' form of government
column8: established single-member geographical districts to proportionally represent both majority and minority elements of the population according to the city's racial demographics
column9: eliminated voting privileges for non-resident property owners
column10: and created the city's current mayor-council form of government. The Chattanooga City Council has nine members
column11: which currently has four African Americans
column12: elected in 2017. The current strong-mayor system started in 1991 after a 1990 citywide election that used the new court-ordered district system.The city's legislative branch is represented by members from nine districts
column13: elected from single-member districts in partisan elections. The current (elected 2017) council members are Chip Henderson (District 1)
column14: Jerry Mitchell (District 2)
column15: Ken Smith (District 3)
column21: and Demetrus Coonrod (District 9).Chattanooga's delegation to the Tennessee House of Representatives includes Robin Smith (R)
column27: Chattanooga is divided between Districts 10 and 11 with Todd Gardenhire (R) and Bo Watson (R) representing each district respectively.

column7: respectively. The Peace Grove has nine trees: a Linden tree
column8: which represents Hamm; a Chinese Elm
column9: which represents Wuxi; a Mediterranean cedar
column10: which represents Givatayim; a White Birch
column11: which represents Nizhny Tagil; a Ginkgo tree
column12: which represents Gangneung; an English Elm
column13: which represents Swindon; a European Hornbeam
column14: which represents Ascoli Piceno; an Oak tree
column15: which represents Wolfsburg; and a Cherry tree
